entry.title: Combined summary - Half-Delegation & Chaperones for Decker Channels
entry.summary: The email conversation discusses different types of delegation scripts in Bitcoin, including full delegation, partial delegation, and half-delegation. These differ in how one signs for a transaction T and can be used in various scenarios, such as with scriptless multisigs and SSS. However, the group notes that if T is signed by S with AnyPrevOut (APO), then T becomes arbitrarily rebindable, so they propose stricter definitions for delegation. Half-delegation is introduced as a solution to prevent unauthorized rebinding of the transaction, where one party can sign a tuple consisting of both a script and a transaction, and R may sign the transaction but revealing T/R does not grant authorization to any other party.The speakers also discuss different signing methods and how they can be used depending on the specifics of the delegation script. They briefly mention chaperone signatures and their usefulness for dynamically picking/rotating keys but agree that APO's design discussion should consider how it might compose with delegation proposals and CTV instead of revisiting chaperone signatures. Finally, the group notes how half-delegation can be derived from full delegation and a covenant and considers how the combination of delegation, CTV, and APO may be sufficient for making chaperone signatures work. Overall, the email conversation provides a detailed analysis of delegation scripts and their potential applications in Bitcoin transactions.
